Award.AwardTitle: OCE-RIG: Variability in Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) strength and hydrological conditions in the central Sahara/Sahel during the Pliocene-Pleistocene
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, the principal investigator will examine past AMOC variability and hydrology in the Sahel using a multi-proxy geochemical approach.

Changes in the strength of the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (AMOC) are known to have a major influence on global climate with the areas around the North Atlantic, including Europe, North America, and northwest Africa. It is predicted that the AMOC may slow down during the 21st century, based on current model simulations from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Therefore, it is important to develop a better understanding of past AMOC variability and its impacts on ocean and continental climates as well as to further develop and refine methods for fingerprinting past AMOC variability. A distinctive feature of AMOC slowdown in the tropical North Atlantic is surface cooling accompanied by shallow subsurface (>30 m) warming. A recent study of the tropical N Atlantic demonstrated that organic geochemical temperature proxies can be used to simultaneously reconstruct surface and subsurface water temperatures.

Through this research effort, the AMOC variability and hydrological conditions in the Sahel will be reconstructed by using a multi-proxy geochemical approach to examine sediments from ODP Hole 660A. This project is designed to test the hypothesis that the characteristic AMOC signature of anti-correlated variation between surface and subsurface water temperatures in the tropical N Atlantic also existed on longer multi-millennial to million-year timescales. This research will provide new records of sea surface temperature (SST), subsurface temperature, and continental vegetation and hydrology during the Pliocene-Pleistocene, which will be used to examine relationships between AMOC and continental hydrology. A particular focus is on the mid-Pliocene warm period, an analog for future warming on Earth, and during the onset and intensification of Northern Hemisphere glaciations in the late Pliocene, when major steps in mammalian and hominin evolution occurred. A new Plio-Pleistocene SST record generated by this work will be used to examine the evolution of zonal and latitudinal SST gradients.

Education is an important part of the broader impacts of this project. The educational aspects of this proposal consist of training a graduate student, two undergraduates, and six high school science teachers. The proposed activities will introduce high school students to the exciting subject of ocean sciences and provide them with information on career opportunities in this field. In an effort to increase awareness of the ocean sciences to under-represented groups, as well as overall participation in the ocean sciences, science teachers will be recruited from high schools lacking Earth Sciences curriculum. The high school teachers will visit the University of Massachusetts-Amherst during the summer and work with the PI and graduate student to produce classroom activities that can be incorporated into high school chemistry, biology and physics courses. Subsequently, the PI, undergraduates and graduate student will visit the home high school of each teacher during the academic year to inform students about career opportunities in the ocean sciences.

This project is supported under the NSF Ocean Sciences Research Initiation Grant (OCE-RIG) program, with goals to support novel research by early career scientists and increase the diversity of the U.S. ocean sciences workforce and research community. With OCE-RIG support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish themselves in an independent research career related to ocean sciences and broaden participation of under-represented groups in the ocean sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical North Africa is a region today characterized by environmental contrasts. The Sahara Desert is among the most arid regions on Earth but rainforest occupies the central equatorial portion of the African continent. The distribution of rainfall in North Africa is likely to be modified in the future due to anthropogenic climate change. However, the processes responsible for controlling both the amount and distribution of rainfall across North Africa are not yet fully understood. Investigations of climate conditions in the geological past afford opportunities to examine North African rainfall at times when global climate was significantly warmer than today, providing information on how future climate change may influence this heavily populated region.

Today, the temperature of the surface oceans surrounding Africa is an important factor influencing the distribution and amount of continental rainfall. In the Atlantic Ocean, surface and shallow subsurface currents carry warm and salty water from the equator north toward the poles where cooling occurs. At the high latitudes, dense and cold waters sink and return as deep, southward flowing currents. This process, Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), is important for re-distributing heat and has a major influence on global climate. The region of North Africa is particularly sensitive to changes in AMOC strength. When this process weakens or slows down, it results in reduced rainfall and arid conditions in North Africa through intensification the Northeast Trade Winds, which increase moisture export from the continent while cooling tropical Atlantic surface waters.

In this study “OCE-RIG: Variability in Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) strength and hydrological conditions in the central Sahara/Sahel during the Pliocene-Pleistocene”, a previously collected sediment core, collected from 10°N offshore Guinea, was studied to investigate relationships between AMOC strength, sea surface temperatures and rainfall in continental North Africa over the time period from 4 to 0.5 million years ago (Ma). The study interval includes the Pliocene (5.332 to 2.588 Ma), which is the most recent epoch in Earth's history when global climate was significantly warmer than today for a sustained period of time and when atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations were similar to today. Organic geochemical techniques were used to reconstruct surface and shallow subsurface water temperatures (to examine past AMOC variability) and plant leaf wax deuterium isotopes were used to examine the isotopic composition of past rainfall (an indicator of precipitation amount). These new climate records were used to examine relationships between AMOC, sea surface temperature and rainfall amount in North Africa during the Pliocene.

This study yielded novel results. In the period from ~2.0 Ma to 0.4 Ma, organic geochemical techniques appear to track AMOC fluctuations reflected in surface and subsurface temperature reconstructions. Although numerous studies established that AMOC slowdowns are closely related to arid conditions in North Africa today and also during the late Pleistocene, results of this work suggest that changes in AMOC, or sea surface temperatures, were not the main factor controlling rainfall during the time period examined here. The new Pliocene leaf wax deuterium isotope record generated reveals that North Africa received greater rainfall than today during specific times within the Pliocene, a result predicted by some climate models for future conditions in this region. However, the Pliocene was also characterized by high variability with conditions fluctuating between relatively wet and relatively arid.
